title: Twelve BBC women set to take corporation to task over equal pay, as Samira Ahmed launches landmark case
text:
A dozen BBC women are poised to take the corporation to tribunal over equal pay, it emerged on Monday, as Samira Ahmed launched a landmark case for £500,000 in back pay.

Ahmed is arguing that as a presenter of Newswatch, the BBC News programme, she was doing an equivalent job to Jeremy Vine when he was presenter of BBC One’s Points of View.

Yet she was paid just £440 per episode while Vine received up to £3,000 per show. The programmes have similar formats, airing viewers’ concerns about BBC content and interviews with the executives responsible.

The BBC said that the roles were not equal because Points of View has a long history as a popular entertainment programme, and Vine is a household name.

Ahmed is the first BBC presenter to take her equal pay claim all the way to tribunal in a movement that began when the corporation was compelled to publish details of its gender pay gap in 2017, sparking a revolt by women employees.
